description.narrative: SG Ghana is a tier II universal bank in Ghana. The Bank, formerly known as SG-SSB Limited, was incorporated in Ghana in 1976 with the Social Security and National Insurance Trust (SSNIT) as its sole shareholder. In 2003, SG Financial Services Holding, a wholly owned subsidiary of Societe Generale SA, acquired 51% of the capital of the Bank and in 2009 increased the stake to 52.24%, making it the majority shareholder. The Bank is listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) and provides banking services to corporate, retail and SME clients through a network of 37 branches across Ghana. IFC will offer Societe Generale Ghana (SG Ghana or the Bank) a senior loan of up to US$30 million with a maturity of 1 year, renewable up to two times at IFCs discretion for a total period of 3 years. The purpose of the IFC investment is to provide trade-related, working capital loans to importers and distributors of critical energy and food commodities and machinery and equipment.

The Facility is expected to have the following specific development impacts: i) Increased Access to Financing for SMEs: Limited access to finance is considered a key constraint to private sector growth. Increased access to finance is indispensable to grow the competitiveness of SMEs. By directly financing the short-term needs of a local bank to support SME trade and working capital finance needs, the Project will support SMEs and will have a positive impact on economic activity in an IDA country. ii) Support Financing to Agribusiness Value Chain: By supporting the expansion of SG Ghana''s short-term loan portfolio directed at SMEs operating in agri-commodities, IFC will aim to strengthen the value chain by allowing traders and distributors to increase their imports and make foodstuffs more available in the country. iii) Support access to energy in Ghana: Continuous energy distribution is critical for sustaining key economic activities, including transportation, cooking and the operation of businesses. A steady supply of critically needed fuel through regular channels will help to improve affordability and help diminish the risk of any disruptions in the country''s supply chains.
